newsitem.title: GERMANY: Boeing ready to pay crash compensation-report.
newsitem.headline: Boeing ready to pay crash compensation-report.

text.p: A German magazine reported on Saturday Boeing Co. was prepared to pay compensation to the families of 189 victims, mainly German tourists, of a Boeing 757 plane crash in February 1996 off the Dominican Republic.

Spiegel said Berlin lawyer Elmar Giemulla representing 70 relatives of crash victims' said the U.S. airline manufacturer said on April 2 it was prepared to pay compensation in cases where financial support was needed "for humanitarian reasons".
The company said this would apply to children who lost their parents for example, Spiegel said in a report released ahead of publication on Monday.
Giemulla said he would meet Boeing's lawyers at their headquarters in Seattle to discuss the details of the payments, Spiegel said.
It said Boeing spokesman John Dern had declined comment on the size of the payments but said sources close to the victims' families cited payments of 18 million dollars.
A joint U.S. and Dominican report put the accident down to human error in a report last October.

In the report, the Dominican office of Civil Aviation and the U.S. National Transportation Safety Board said the probable cause of the crash was the crew's "confusion and lack of knowledge" of the aircraft's systems.

The 757 leased to the Dominican national airline Alas Nacionales by Turkish carrier Birgenair plunged into the sea on February 9 shortly after taking off from the Dominican resort of Puerto Plata. All 189 people on board died in the disaster.
Spiegel said that since then Boeing had made amendments to the instructions in the 757's cockpit handbook for pilots.
